info: I got married to Tory (née Choate) Hasler on Jan. 6 in Washington, D.C.

The most important event of my life: I met Tory (who I married over six years later)
Opened Modern Times Coffeehouse on March 1
My history project, Project Page One because I wanted to read, see, and year the great works of Western culture
Moved into the apartment at 16th and U St., where I first lived alone
Graduated with my International Relations degree in May
Graduated with my History degree in December
Finished my history thesis, an analysis of a pamphlet war between English parliamentarians and landholders in the remaining colonies of the Western hemisphere following the American Revolution
Hatched a plan to open a coffeehouse in an abandoned building in Fort Reno park
Studied abroad at the University of Havana. I went in order to study black markets and ended up writing a thesis in Spanish on poetry
My internship at the Organization of American States
Broke up with my longtime girlfriend I'd had since high school
Bought my first new car, a Mini Cooper
Started boxing, a hobby I would keep up for many years
Became a mentor for freshman students in the School of International Service
Started working at the coffeehouse at Politics & Prose Bookstore, operated by Sirius Coffee Co., because I missed the bohemian coffeeshops of Austin
Work as a translator for a landscaping company in Austin
Moved to 5227 Connecticut Ave., which I came to call the 'House on Jenifer St.'
Visited Spain for spring break just to see a bullfight after I read The Sun Also Rises
Graduated from Westlake High School in Austin, TX
Shocked everyone at my competitive high school by choosing American University, rather than Georgetown, for college
Got my first restaurant job at a crummy Italian restaurant where I worked as a busboy
Started college at American University
Moved into the 6th floor of Hughes Hall

Management of business and financial operations
Operated by the LLC I started, Coup d'Etat Coffee Co.
Felt I could do more for the world by operating a neighborhood coffeehouse than the career in international development that I had planned
'In the black' after eighteen months
Met the woman I married here (she was a customer)
Maintained a great rapport with a huge number of regular guests
Generally worked myself into the ground
I waited tables. Not complicated.
